revision.text:
This is a list of cases from the '''January 1918 – December 1920 flu pandemic''', commonly referred to as the [[Spanish flu]].
To maintain morale, [[World War I|wartime]] censors minimized early reports of illness and mortality in Germany, the United Kingdom, France, and the United States.<ref>{{cite web| last = Valentine| first = Vikki| title = Origins of the 1918 Pandemic: The Case for France| url = https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5222069| publisher = [[NPR]]| access-date= 2 October 2011| date = 20 February 2006| ref = harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Anderson|first=Susan|title=Analysis of Spanish flu cases in 1918–1920 suggests transfusions might help in bird flu pandemic|url=http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2006-08/acop-aos082806.php|publisher=[[American College of Physicians]]|access-date=2 October 2011|date=29 August 2006}}</ref> Papers were free to report the epidemic's effects in neutral Spain (such as the grave illness of [[King Alfonso XIII]]).<ref>{{cite encyclopedia| editor1-first = Maria| editor1-last = Porras-Gallo| editor2-first = Ryan A.| editor2-last = Davis | name-list-format = vanc| title = The Spanish Influenza Pandemic of 1918–1919: Perspectives from the Iberian Peninsula and the Americas| publisher = University of Rochester Press| date = 2014| isbn = 978-1-58046-496-3| volume = 30| encyclopedia = Rochester Studies in Medical History| url = https://books.google.com/?id=-j53BQAAQBAJ&pg=PA51&dq=spanish+flu+davis#v=onepage&q&f=false| ref = harv}}</ref> This created a false impression of Spain as especially hard hit,<ref>{{cite book| last = Barry| first = John M. | name-list-format = vanc| authorlink = John M. Barry| title = The Great Influenza: The Epic Story of the Greatest Plague in History| publisher = Viking Penguin| date = 2004| isbn = 978-0-670-89473-4| ref = harv}}</ref> thereby giving rise to the pandemic's nickname, "Spanish Flu".<ref>{{cite web| last = Galvin| first = John | name-list-format = vanc| title = Spanish Flu Pandemic: 1918| url = http://www.popularmechanics.com/science/environment/natural-disasters/4219884| publisher = [[Popular Mechanics]]| access-date=2 October 2011| date = 31 July 2007| ref = harv}}</ref>
==Fatalities== <!-- REAL PEOPLE ONLY --><!-- TWILIGHT FANS PLEASE NOTE --> Listed alphabetically by surname * [[Turki I bin Abdulaziz Al Saud]], Eldest son of [[Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia]] (1919) * [[Francisco de Paula Rodrigues Alves]], Brazilian re-elected president, died before taking office (January 16, 1919)<ref>{{Cite book | year=2004 | title=Soldiers of the Pátria: a history of the Brazilian Army, 1889–1937 | author=[[Frank D. McCann]] | publisher=Stanford University Press | isbn=978-0-8047-3222-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xDep7jGaHPwC&pg=RA2-PA191&dq=Francisco+influenza}}</ref> * [[Guillaume Apollinaire]], French poet (November 9, 1918) * [[Felix Arndt]], American pianist (October 16, 1918) * [[Dudley John Beaumont]], husband of the Dame of Sark (November 24, 1918)<ref name=hathway59>{{cite book |last=Hathaway |first=Sibyl |authorlink=Sibyl Hathaway |coauthors= |title=Dame of Sark: An Autobiography|edition=2nd|year=1962 |publisher=Coward-McCann, Inc. |location=[[New York City|New York]] |isbn= | url=https://archive.org/details/dameofsark006367mbp|page=59}}</ref> * [[Louis Botha]], first Prime Minister of the [[Union of South Africa]] (August 27, 1919)<ref name="duncan-16">{{Harvnb|Duncan|2003|p=16}}</ref> * [[Randolph Bourne]], American progressive writer and public intellectual, (December 22, 1918)<ref name="dMAC Health Digest">[http://www.dmacdigest.com/flu1918.html dMAC Health Digest].</ref> * [[Amadeo de Souza Cardoso]], Portuguese painter, (October 25, 1918) * [[Ivan Cankar]], Slovenian Writer, (December 11, 1918) * [[Kate Carmack]], founder of the [[Klondike Gold Rush]] (March 29, 1920) * [[Larry Chappell]], American baseball player, (November 8, 1918) * [[Rose Cleveland]], First Lady of the United States of America, sister of President [[Grover Cleveland]] (November 22, 1918) * [[Carrie Cornplanter]], Native American artist and descendant of diplomant [[Cornplanter]] (late 1918) * [[Gaby Deslys]], French actress and dancer (February 11, 1920) * [[Anton Dilger]], medical doctor, mastermind of Germany's World War I secret bioterror sabotage * [[John Francis Dodge]] (January 14, 1920), American automobile manufacturing pioneer * [[Horace Elgin Dodge]] (December 10, 1920), American automobile manufacturing pioneer * [[Admiral Dot|"Admiral" Dot]] (1864–1918), American circus performer under [[P. T. Barnum]]<ref name="PBS. Influenza 1918. Victims">{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/influenza/sfeature/victims.html |title=Influenza 1918 - Among the Victims |work=American Experience, PBS |accessdate=2009-04-27}}</ref> * [[Angus Douglas]], Scottish international footballer, (December 14, 1918) * [[Charles A. Doyen]], United States Marine Corps Brigadier General (October 6, 1918) * [[George Freeth]], father of modern surfing and lifeguard (April 7, 1919) * [[Harold Gilman]], British painter (February 12, 1919) * [[Henry G. Ginaca]], American engineer, inventor of the Ginaca machine (October 19, 1918) * [[Myrtle Gonzalez]], American film actress (October 22, 1918)<ref name="dMAC Health Digest"/> * [[Edward Kidder Graham]], President of the [[University of North Carolina]] (October 26, 1918) * [[Charles Tomlinson Griffes]], American composer (April 8, 1920) * [[Eremia Grigorescu]], Romanian General during World War I (July 21, 1919) * [[Wilhelm Gross (mathematician)|Wilhelm Gross]], Austrian mathematician (October 22, 1918) * [[Sophie Halberstadt-Freud]], daughter of Austrian psychoanalyst [[Sigmund Freud]], (1920) * [[Joe Hall]], [[Montreal Canadiens]] [[defenceman (ice hockey)|ice hockey defenceman]], a member of the [[Hockey Hall of Fame]] (April 6, 1919) * [[Alfred Hindmarsh]], New Zealand Labour Party leader, lawyer and politician. * [[Phoebe Hearst]], mother of [[William Randolph Hearst]], (April 13, 1919) * [[William F. Hooley]], member of the successful U.S. singing group of the 1910s, the [[American Quartet (ensemble)|American Quartet]]. * [[Shelley Hull]], American stage actor, (January 14, 1919) * [[Margit Kaffka]], Hungarian writer and poet, (December 1, 1918) * [[Joseph Kaufman]], American actor and film director, (February 1, 1918) * [[Lyman W.V. Kennon]], American brigadier general (September 9, 1918) * [[Vera Kholodnaya]], Russian actress (February 16, 1919) * [[Gustav Klimt]], Austrian painter, (February 6, 1918) * [[Bohumil Kubišta]], Czech painter, (November 27, 1918) * [[Hans E. Lau]], Danish astronomer, (October 16, 1918)<ref name="dMAC Health Digest"/> * [[Julian L'Estrange]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shakespeare.emory.edu/actordisplay.cfm?actorid%3D34 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-04-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424152806/http://shakespeare.emory.edu/actordisplay.cfm?actorid=34 |archivedate=2016-04-24 |df= }}</ref> English stage and screen actor (October 22, 1918) * [[Ruby Lindsay]], Australian illustrator and painter, (March 12, 1919) * [[Harold Lockwood]], American silent film star, (October 19, 1918)<ref name="PBS. Influenza 1918. Victims"/> * [[Rosalia Lombardo]], Italian daughter of General Lombardo (December 6, 1920) * [[Jacinta and Francisco Marto|Francisco Marto]], Portuguese ''[[Our Lady of Fatima|Fátima]] child'' (April 4, 1919) * [[Jacinta and Francisco Marto|Jacinta Marto]], Portuguese ''[[Our Lady of Fatima|Fátima]] child'' (February 20, 1920) * [[Alan Arnett McLeod]], Canadian soldier and [[Victoria Cross]] recipient, (6 November 1918) * [[Dan McMichael]], [[head coach|manager]] of Scottish [[association football]] club [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] (1919) * [[Morane-Saulnier|Leon Morane]], French aircraft company [http://www.earlyaviators.com/emoranel.htm founder] and pre-World War I aviator (October 20, 1918) * [[William Francis Murray]], Postmaster of Boston and former U.S. Representative (September 21, 1918) * [[William Osler]], Canadian physician, co founder of [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]], (December 29, 1919) * [[Ōyama Sutematsu]], first Japanese woman to receive a college degree (February, 1919) * Sir [[Hubert Parry]], [[United Kingdom|British]] [[composer]], (October 7, 1918) * [[Henry Ragas]], American pianist of the [[Original Dixieland Jass Band]], (February 18, 1919) * [[Stephen Reynolds (writer)|Stephen Sydney Reynolds]], English writer, (February 14, 1919) * [[William Leefe Robinson]], [[Victoria Cross]] recipient, (December 31, 1918) * [[Edmond Rostand]], French dramatist, best known for his play ''[[Cyrano de Bergerac (play)|Cyrano de Bergerac]]'', (December 2, 1918) * [[Morton Schamberg]], [[American modernism|American modernist artist]] in 1918. * [[Egon Schiele]], Austrian painter (October 31, 1918, [[Vienna]]).<ref name="whitford">Frank Whitford, Expressionist Portraits, Abbeville Press, 1987, p. 46. {{ISBN|0-89659-780-6}}</ref> * [[Reggie Schwarz]], South African cricketer and rugby player (November 18, 1918)<ref name="dMAC Health Digest"/> * [[Robert W. Speer]], Mayor of Denver (May 14, 1918) * [[Walter Stradling]], English born cinematographer (July 1918) * [[ʻAnaseini Takipō]], Queen Dowager of Tonga (November 26, 1918) <ref>{{cite book|last=Eustis|first=Nelson|title=The King of Tonga: A Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S151AAAAMAAJ|year=1997|publisher=Hobby Investment|location=Adelaide|isbn=978-0-646-33077-8|oclc=38837175|page=64}}</ref> * [[Frederick Trump]], Grandfather of the President of the United States [[Donald Trump]] (May 27, 1918) * [[Willard Dickerman Straight]], American investment banker, publisher, reporter, Army Reserve officer and diplomat (December 1, 1918) * [[Yakov Sverdlov]], [[Bolshevik]] party leader and official of the [[Russian Republic]] established by the [[February 1917 Revolution]] (March 16, 1919) * [[Mark Sykes]], British politician and diplomat, body exhumed 2008 for scientific research (February 16, 1919) * [[Dark Cloud (actor)]], aka Elijah Tahamont, American Indian actor, in Los Angeles (1918). * [[Prince Umberto, Count of Salemi]], Member of Italian royal family, (October 19, 1918) * [[Prince Erik, Duke of Västmanland]] (''Erik Gustav Ludvig Albert Bernadotte''), Prince of Sweden (September 20, 1918) * [[King Watzke]], American violinist and bandleader, (1920)<ref name="dMAC Health Digest"/> * [[Max Weber]], German political economist and sociologist (June 14, 1920) * David Franklin Williams, Father of American film actress, [[Myrna Loy]] (November 1918) * [[Bill Yawkey]], [[Major League Baseball]] executive and owner of the [[Detroit Tigers]], in [[Augusta, Georgia]], US (March 5, 1919) * [[Ella Flagg Young]], American educator (October 26, 1918)
==In utero deaths== Children of women who were pregnant during the pandemic ran the risk of lifelong effects. One in three of the more than 25 million who contracted the flu in the United States was a woman of childbearing age. A study of US census data from 1960 to 1980 found that the children born to this group of women had more physical ailments and a lower lifetime income than those born a few months earlier or later.<ref>{{cite book |title=Superfreakonomics: global cooling, patriotic prostitutes, and why suicide bombers should buy life insurance |author1=Steven D. Levitt |author2=Stephen J. Dubner |publisher=William Morrow |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-06-088957-9 |pages=59, 230}} citing "Is the 1918 Influenza Pandemic Over? Long-Term Effects of In Utero Influenza Exposure in the Post-1940 U.S Population," ''Journal of Political Economy'' 114 no. 4 (2006); and Douglas Almond and Bhashkar Mazumder, "The 1918 Influenza Pandemic and Subsequent Health Outcomes: An Analysis of SIPP Data," ''Recent Developments in Health Economics'' 95 no. 2 (May 2005)</ref> The study also found that persons born in states with more severe exposure to the pandemic experienced worse outcomes than persons born in states with less severe exposures.<ref>{{cite book |title=Innovation in Global Health Governance: Critical Cases |work=Global environmental governance series |author1=Andrew Fenton Cooper |author2=John J. Kirton |publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-7546-4872-7 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=kZRaDr1VzR4C&pg=PA139 139]}}</ref>
==Notable survivors==<!-- REAL PEOPLE ONLY --> * [[Alexandrine of Mecklenburg-Schwerin]] (1879–1952), Queen of Denmark<ref name="Collier"/> * [[Alfonso XIII of Spain]] (1886–1941), King of Spain<ref name=Barry_book>Barry 2004</ref> * [[Walter Benjamin]] (1892–1940) [[German-Jewish]] philosopher and [[Marxist]] literary critic.<ref name="Scholem, Gershom">Sholem, Gershom. ''Walter Benjamin: The Story of a Friendship.'' Trans. The Jewish Publication Society of America. London: Faber & Faber, 1982. 76.</ref> * [[Raymond Chandler]] (1888–1959), American novelist and screenwriter.<ref>[http://www.thekeptgirl.com/2017/07/the-clews-from-raymond-chandlers-war.html The clews from Raymond Chandler’s war], By Kim Cooper, July 23, 2017, Kim Cooper's "The Kept Girl"</ref> * [[Walt Disney]] (1901–1966), cartoonist.<ref name="Collier"/> * [[Margaret Dumont]] (1882–1965), American stage and motion picture actress * [[Peter Fraser (New Zealand politician)|Peter Fraser]] (1884–1950), New Zealand prime minister.<ref name="Collier"/> * [[Amelita Galli-Curci]] (1882–1963), Italian operatic soprano *[[Greta Garbo]] (1905–1990), Swedish/American motion picture actress * [[Robert Graves]] (1895–1985), English poet, translator and novelist. * [[Lillian Gish]] (1893–1993), American early motion picture actress.<ref>[[Lillian Gish]]: The Movies, Mr. Griffith, and Me, {{ISBN|0-13-536649-6}}.</ref> * [[Haile Selassie I]] (1892–1975), Emperor of [[Ethiopia]].<ref name=Marcus>Harold Marcus, ''Haile Sellassie I: The formative years, 1892–1936'' (Trenton: Red Sea Press, 1996), pp. 36f; Pankhurst 1990, p. 48f.</ref> * [[Friedrich Hayek]] (1899–1992), economist and Nobel Laureate * [[Joseph Joffre]] (1852–1931), French [[World War I]] general, [[First Battle of the Marne|victor of the Marne]].<ref name="Collier"/> * [[Jim Jordan (actor)|Jim Jordan]] (1896–1988), American actor best known as [[Fibber McGee]]<ref name="Radio">{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.niu.edu/1993/ihy930345.html|title=Jim and Marian Jordan's Contributions to Radio|publisher=www.lib.niu.edu|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref> * [[David Lloyd George]] (1863–1945), British prime minister.<ref name="Collier"/> * [[Franz Kafka]] (1883–1924), [[German language|German-speaking]] [[Jewish]] author<ref>[http://jewishnews.at/jewish-news-from-austria-21/the-impossibility-of-being-kafka.html The Impossibility of Being Kafka], December 24, 2008, Jewish News From Austria</ref> * [[Prince Maximilian of Baden]] (1867–1929), [[Chancellor of Germany (German Reich)|Chancellor of Germany]] during the [[Armistice with Germany (Compiègne)|armistice]].<ref name="Collier"/> * [[William Keepers Maxwell, Jr.]] (August 16, 1908 – July 31, 2000) American novelist and editor * [[Edvard Munch]], (1863–1944) [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]] painter.<ref>Munch Museum, "A timeline of Munch's life".[http://www.munch.museum.no/content.aspx?id=14 Munch Museum]. Accessed 2009-05-24. [https://www.webcitation.org/5h5mFXCHn Archived] 2009-05-27.</ref> * [[Georgia O'Keeffe]], (1887–1986) American [[modernism|modernist]] painter.<ref>[[Roxana Robinson]], Georgia O'Keeffe: A Life. Roosevelt]] (1882–1945), American president<ref name="Collier"/> * [[Leó Szilárd]] (1898–1964), [[nuclear physics|nuclear physicist]], discoverer of the [[nuclear chain reaction]].<ref>[[Richard Rhodes]], The Making of the Atomic Bomb, {{ISBN|0-684-81378-5}}.</ref> * [[Robert Walser (writer)|Robert Walser]] (1878–1956), Swiss author. * [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor]] (1859–1941)<ref name="Collier"/> * [[Woodrow Wilson]] (1856–1924) American president.<ref name="Collier"/>

page.title: List of countries by body mass index

revision.comment: /* DATA on most o0obese(2019) */
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=May 2017}}This page serves as a partial list of countries by adult mean body weight and incidence of obese and overweight populations as calculated by [[body mass index]] (BMI). The data for 2014 was first published by the [[World Health Organization]] in 2015. ==Methodology== {{Main|Body mass index}} [[Arithmetic mean|Mean]] [[body mass index]] (BMI) provides a simplified measure of the comparative weight of populations on a country by country basis. BMI calculates a person's mass (weight) divided by the square of their height. An individual with a BMI of 25 kg/m2 or more is considered overweight. An individual with a BMI of 30 kg/m2 or more is considered obese. The data highlighted on this page comes from [[World Health Organization]] statistics for adult (18 years old and older) populations. Mean BMI data is shown separately for males and females, as well as a combined figure. Mean data highlights the [[central tendency]] of the population data and is but one method of calculating relative body weight between populations. ==Limitations on the usefulness of comparative BMI data== {{Main|Body mass index#Limitations}} There are significant limitations to the usefulness of comparative BMI data cited by both the medical community and statisticians.{{cite web|last1=Olson|first1=Samantha|title=BMI Is No Longer A Good Indication Of Healthy Weight; Here Are 6 Better Ways To Measure Your Health|url=http://www.medicaldaily.com/body-mass-index-bmi-calculator-healthy-weight-obesity-372852|website=Medical Daily|date=9 February 2016}} BMI data has significant weaknesses in terms of scalability and in accounting for variations in physical characteristics. ==DATA on most obese(2018)== {{anchor|table}} Data published in 2015.{{cite web|title=Global status report on noncommunicable diseases 2014|url=http://www.who.int/topics/obesity/en/|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=10 April 2018}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center" |- style="background:#ececec; vertical-align:top;" ! revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} [[File:Nkosi's Haven HIV AIDS Orphanage.jpg|thumb|Nkosi's Haven HIV AIDS Orphanage entrance and sign.]] '''Nkosi's Haven''' is an [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] in the [[Johannesburg, South Africa]] area that offers residential, holistic care and support for mothers and their children whose lives have been impacted by [[HIV/AIDS]].<ref name="About">{{cite web|last1=Nkosi's Haven|title=About|url=http://nkosishaven.org/who-we-are/|publisher=Nkosi's Haven|accessdate=20 November 2016}}</ref> Nkosi's Haven also provides support for [[orphan]]s, HIV/AIDS affected or not.<ref name="About" /> It aims to improve the productivity of their residents through providing access to medical care, therapy, education and skill building workshops. The goal is to empower residents while providing a safe, dignified home in hopes that all mothers and children are able to become responsible and contributing members of society.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal|last1=Ross|first1=Eleanor|last2=Dube|first2=Nkosiyazi|title=Sanctuary or double-edged sword? Challenges confronting adolescents living at Nkosi's Haven in Johannesburg, South Africa|journal=SAHARA-J: Journal of Social Aspects of HIV/AIDS|date=13 December 2012|volume=9|issue=4|pages=200–209}}</ref>
Nkosi's Haven was named after [[Nkosi Johnson]], an AIDS activist who dedicated his life to ensuring that mothers and their children are kept together under the belief that no mother should have to leave her child due to HIV diagnosis.<ref name="About" /> It is a recognized non-governmental organization that is largely funded by international donors and governmental organizations.<ref name="John Murray">{{cite journal|last1=Murray|first1=John|title=Collaborative Community-Based Care for South African Children Orphaned by HIV/AIDS|journal=Journal for Specialists in Pediatric Nursing|date=3 January 2010|volume=15|issue=1|pages=88–92}}</ref> Funding is allocated to assist accommodations, which include housing, food, water, medication, and hospice care. It also assists with education costs such as school fees, uniforms, and other expenditures.<ref name="John Murray" /> Residents share household tasks among themselves, including tasks such as cooking, cleaning, laundry, and childcare. <ref name="John Murray" />
At the time of inception, it was the first and only care centre in South Africa that provided residential care for mothers living with HIV/AIDS and their children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bpsd.mb.ca/hmk/freeman/la/reading/raz_lz03_successstories.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161223134612/http://www.bpsd.mb.ca/hmk/freeman/la/reading/raz_lz03_successstories.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 December 2016|title=Success Stories|date=|website=www.readinga-z.com|publisher=Reading A-Z|last1=Freed|first1=Kira|accessdate=20 November 2016}}</ref>
== Mission statement ==
“Through all of the work we do, we ensure that our residents learn how to live with AIDS, not die from it.” <ref name="What We Do">{{cite web|last1=Nkosi's Haven|title=What We Do|url=http://nkosishaven.org/what-we-do/|website=www.nkosishaven.org|publisher=Nkosi's Haven|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> Nkosi's Haven has built a home in which residents can live free from prejudice and discrimination against HIV/AIDS and children can grow into self-sufficient and responsible members of society.
== Nkosi's biography == {{Infobox person | name = [[Nkosi Johnson]] | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Xolani Nkosi | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1989|02|04}} | birth_place = Johannesburg, South Africa | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2001|06|01|1989|02|04}} | death_place = Johannesburg, South Africa | nationality = South African | other_names = Nkosi Johnson | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = HIV/AIDS Activism | notable_works = Nkosi's Haven }} Nkosi's Haven was named after Nkosi Johnson, a young AIDS activist who died on International [[Children's Day|Children's Day]] in 2001.<ref name="History">{{cite web|last1=Nkosi's Haven|title=Nkosi Johnson's History|url=http://nkosishaven.org/nkosi-johnsons-history/|website=Nkosi's Haven|publisher=Nkosi's Haven|accessdate=24 November 2016}}</ref> Born Xolani Nkosi, Nkosi was infected with HIV through [[mother-to-child transmission]]. Nkosi and his mother were admitted to an AIDS care centre in Johannesburg, where they met Gail Johnson, a volunteer worker.<ref name="History" />
Due to financial restraints, the care centre that Nkosi and his mother were living in closed down. Nkosi's mother's health was deteriorating rapidly and she was unable to keep Nkosi due to her health conditions and financial dependency. She also feared that the community would find out that both herself and Nkosi were HIV positive and exile them.<ref name="Obituary">{{cite news|last1=Beresford|first1=Belinda|title=Nkosi Johnson|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2001/jun/02/guardianobituaries.aids|accessdate=5 December 2016|issue=Special report: Aids|publisher=The Guardian News and Media Limited|date=2 June 2001}}</ref> As a result, Gail Johnson took Nkosi into her care, changing his name to Nkosi Johnson, and became his legal foster mother.<ref name="History" />
Gail Johnson attempted to enroll Nkosi into school in Johannesburg and was faced with backlash as soon as Nkosi's HIV status was made public.<ref name="History" /> In 1997, Johnson took the case to court, winning her case and forcing the South African educational system to revise their admittance policies discriminating against children with AIDS.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/people/gail-johnson|title=Gail Johnson|last=South African History Online|first=|date=16 August 2016|website=www.sahistory.org.za|publisher=South African History Online|access-date=5 December 2016}}</ref>
After Nkosi's experience with discrimination due to his health status and the forced separation between him and his mother, Nkosi's dream was to create an HIV/AIDS care centre in which children and their mothers could live freely without prejudice or discrimination because of their health status. With the help of his foster mother, Gail, Nkosi opened Nkosi's Haven in 1999, providing hundreds of mothers and their children with a safe space and communal environment.<ref name="History" />
Nkosi's journey made him the national figure in the fight against AIDS.<ref name="History" /> In July 2000, Nkosi wrote and presented a speech at the [[XIII International AIDS Conference, 2000|13th International Aids Conference]], held in [[Durban]], which was televised worldwide.<ref name="Thom Anso">{{cite news|last1=Thom|first1=Anso|title=Nkosi Johnson, you were the Hector Pieterson of the Aids generation|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-07-10-nkosi-johnson-you-were-the-hector-pieterson-of-the-aids-generation/#.WDInK2QrK00|accessdate=20 November 2016|publisher=Daily Maverick|date=10 July 2016}}</ref> At 11 years old, he spoke to delegates about his experience growing up with HIV. His fight with HIV birthed his dream to raise awareness and erase the stigma of HIV/AIDS through communal, supportive environments and care centres.<ref name="Thom Anso" /> Nkosi is most famously known for his quote, “We are normal. We have hands. We have feet. We can walk, we can talk, we have needs just like everyone else- don't be afraid of us- we are all the same!"<ref name="Thom Anso" />
A year before his death, Nkosi suffered through severe brain damage and viral infections due to AIDS. He was bedridden, emaciated, suffering from seizures and unable to eat solid foods. After battling the disease for 12 years, Nkosi Johnson died in his sleep on 1 June 2001.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Loof|first1=Susanna|title=Young AIDS Activist Dies|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/story?id=81001&page=1|accessdate=6 December 2016|agency=ABC News|publisher=ABC News|date=1 June 2001}}</ref>
Nkosi was given a hero's burial memorial service in Johannesburg with thousands of attendees paying their respects to the late activist.<ref name="History" />
At the time of his death, Nkosi Johnson was South Africa's longest surviving child born with HIV/AIDS.<ref>{{cite journal|date=28 July 2014|title=The critical condition of rhetorical choices The Bush administration's framing of HIV/AIDS as a national security threat in PEPFAR|journal=The Journal of International Communication|volume=21|issue=2|pages=226–240|last1=Yartey|first1=Franklin Nii Amankwah}}</ref> In 2005, he was awarded with the International Children's Peace Prize for his fight against HIV/AIDS and activist efforts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sahistory.org.za/people/nkosi-johnson|title=Nkosi Johnson|website=South African History Online|publisher=South African History Online|last1=South African History Online|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> After his death, [[Nelson Mandela]] released a statement, recognizing Nkosi as an "icon of the struggle for life" who fought fearlessly against HIV/AIDS. He urged everyone to give their support during this time, acknowledging Nkosi as an ambassador for South Africa and its people, especially those living with HIV.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mandela|first1=Nelson|title=Message By Nelson Mandela about Nkosi Johnson|url=http://www.mandela.gov.za/mandela_speeches/2001/0106_nkosi.htm|website=www.mandela.gov.za|publisher=Nelson Mandela Foundation|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref>
Nkosi Johnson's legacy lives on through the work of Nkosi's Haven.
== HIV/AIDS in South Africa == [[South Africa]] has had high rates of [[HIV/AIDS in South Africa|HIV/AIDS]] diagnoses for years, with approximately 6.19 million accounted individuals living with HIV/AIDS in 2015.<ref name="Statistics">{{cite web|last1=Statistics South Africa|title=Mid-year population estimates 2015|url=https://www.statssa.gov.za/publications/P0302/P03022015.pdf|website=Statistics South Africa|publisher=Statistics South Africa|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref> Within the age group of adults aged 15–49 years old, 16.6% of that cohort is HIV positive. HIV/AIDS related deaths have been declining as of recent years, with 2005 being the year with the highest number of deaths in South Africa.<ref name="Statistics" /> Thereafter, [[Management of HIV/AIDS|antiretroviral treatment]] was administered and easily accessible, changing the patterns of HIV/AIDS and extending the lifespan of many South Africans who would have otherwise died at an earlier age.<ref name="Statistics" />
HIV/AIDS related illnesses are still high, with an increase of 4.02 million people living with HIV in South Africa from 2002 to 2015. Statistics South Africa approximates that every one out of five South African females in their reproductive ages are living with HIV.<ref name="Statistics" />
UNAIDS reports that approximately 2.1 million children in South Africa are orphans due to HIV/AIDS related illnesses, with 180,000 deaths occurring in the year of 2015. Women over the age of 15 account for 4 million people living with HIV, and approximately 240,000 children under the age of 14 have been affected by HIV.<ref>{{cite web|last1=UNAIDS|title=HIV and AIDS estimates (2015)|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/regionscountries/countries/southafrica|website=www.unaids.org|publisher=UNAIDS|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref>
Evidence has shown that the HIV/AIDS crisis has had a significant impact on South African family life. Responsibility for children growing up in South African society has been increasingly separate from biological parenthood due to the lack of parental care available.<ref name="Law of SA">{{cite book|last1=van der Merwe|first1=C.G|last2=du Plessis|first2=Jacques E.|title=Introduction to the Law of South Africa|date=2004|publisher=Luwer Law International|location=The Netherlands|isbn=9041122826|page=140}}</ref> Under many circumstances, children often care for their own families due to the circumstances created by the [[Epidemiology of HIV/AIDS|HIV/AIDS epidemic]].<ref name="Law of SA" />
== Nkosi's Haven history ==
=== Berea === In 1999, Nkosi and Gail opened their first Nkosi's Haven location in Berea, Johannesburg. Despite being close to the city centre, selling properties became increasingly difficult in Berea, with the neighbouring area of [[Hillbrow, Johannesburg|Hillbrow]] beside, as it became an area that was frequented with street children and the unemployed.<ref name="Jane Fox">{{cite book|last1=Fox|first1=Jane|title=Nkosi's Story|date=15 September 2011|publisher=New Africa Books|location=South Africa|isbn=0864865333}}</ref> The 1980s was an era of high crime rates in downtown Johannesburg, which neighboured Hillbrow and Berea. After the apartheid ended in the 1990s, many gangs, along with residents from neighbouring townships, moved into the area making it unsafe.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hanes|first1=Stephanie|title=Ponte City – a South African landmark – rises again|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Africa/2008/0212/p20s01-woaf.html|accessdate=21 December 2016|publisher=The Christian Science Monitor|date=12 February 2008}}</ref> Thus, the property was offered to Gail Johnson, rent free for 5 years.<ref name="Jane Fox" />[[File:Hillbrow Johannesburg 01.jpg|thumb|The intersection of Pretoria Street and Banket Street in Hillbrow, Johannesburg]]
The house was located on 23 Mitchell street and consisted of four bedrooms, one bathroom upstairs and one downstairs, a lounge, a room used as a dormitory, and a courtyard.<ref name="Jane Fox" /> Renovations and repairs were needed, in addition to furniture and basic house necessities. To raise funds for the completion of the house, Gail, a former public relations consultant, held a “kitchen tea” in which a wish list was created and publicized in the media and to those who were potential contributors.<ref name="Jane Fox" /> At the tea, Gail explained the reasons behind the creation of Nkosi's Haven. She explained that Nkosi's Haven was to offer a [[kibbutz]] style of living in which residents would take turns at cooking, cleaning, caring for the children, and helping care for each other as needed.<ref name="Jane Fox" /> Gail also told the guests that they already reached capacity for residence at the house. At the time, the house fit nine mothers and their children with presumed costs starting at R28,000 monthly.<ref name="Jane Fox" /> The results of the kitchen tea were successful and Gail managed to fundraise R45,000 worth of furniture and equipment, free electrical services, along with appliances valued at R30,000 for the nursery and dormitory.<ref name="Jane Fox" />
After 3 years in operation, Nkosi's Haven saw need for a second home as the Berea residence was rapidly expanding with mothers and children living with HIV/AIDS and orphans. In 2002, a separate plot of land was purchased south of Johannesburg. Upon development, both residences catered to over 160 residents and their children providing meals, medication, education, daily necessities for residents living with or without HIV/AIDS, and care for orphans.<ref name=":1" />
Due to financial restraints, in 2012, the NGO sold its property in Berea and moved all occupants to Nkosi's Haven Village in Alan Manor, South of Johannesburg.<ref name="Theresa Taylor">{{cite web|last1=Taylor|first1=Theresa|title=Nkosi’s Haven to move from Berea|url=http://www.iol.co.za/the-star/nkosis-haven-to-move-from-berea-1310700|website=www.iol.co.za/|publisher=The Star|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> Costs for operating the Berea house were as much as R150,000 to R180,000 monthly, and because all occupants could be accommodated at the village, consolidating all residents meant that no one was left without a home or unemployed. Given that Nkosi's Haven village had bigger plans in motion, the shift would focus on different things such as training opportunities for residents at the newly purchased farm and other facilities at the Nkosi's Haven Village.<ref name="Theresa Taylor" /> These opportunities were unavailable in Berea due to space and financial constraints. Gail reasoned this by stating, “We are not the Titanic. We are consolidating... it makes sense to consolidate and save money.”<ref name="Theresa Taylor" />
=== Alan Manor === [[File:Nkosi's Haven Village.jpg|thumb|Inside Nkosi's Haven Village. Pictured in the background is one of 17 cottages used to house resident mothers, their children, and orphans.]] Nkosi's Haven grew so rapidly that in 2002, a second 2.5 acre plot of land was purchased in the Alan Manor neighbourhood, south of Johannesburg to begin the development of Nkosi's Haven Village. This was made possible through a grant from the [[Gauteng]] Department of Housing, Social Housing and Special Needs.<ref name="Nkosi's Haven Village">{{cite web|last1=Nkosi's Haven|title=Nkosi's Haven Village|url=http://nkosishaven.org/what-we-do/nkosis-haven-village/|website=www.nkosishaven.org|publisher=Nkosi's Haven|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> Although the project received backlash from neighbouring communities, key sponsors made the initiative possible and enabled Nkosi's Haven to host up to 180 residents at a time.<ref name="Nkosi's Haven Village" />
Nkosi's Haven Village in Alan Manor consists of 17 cottages in which residents reside in, a sickbay, a library, a baby day care, a therapy block, a kitchen, a bakery, and a leisure block. There are also workshops and classrooms such as a computer room and an arts room for additional education and skill building. Administrative offices are located near the sickbay.<ref name="Nkosi's Haven Village" /> All residents share household tasks and duties that help with the functioning of the village, providing a sense of leadership and empowerment to residents through skill-building activities.
==== Bakery ====
In 2010, Nkosi's Haven received a bakery donation from the South African Whole Grain Bread Project (SAGWBP). In addition to the onsite bakery container donation, SAGWBP donated enough bread mix for six months.<ref name="Bakery">{{cite web|last1=Nkosi's Haven|title=Unique Container Bakery Turns On the Heat at Nkosi’s Haven Village|url=http://nkosishaven.org/unique-container-bakery-turns-on-the-heat-at-nkosis-haven-village/|website=www.nkosishaven.org|publisher=Nkosi's Haven|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> White and brown loaves are still produced for resident consumption and are marketed to other organizations in the community at a competitive price.<ref name="Bakery" /> The residents of Nkosi's Haven Village handle oversight of operations in the bakery. While providing skill-building opportunities, those who assist can also earn a stipend for their labour.<ref name="Bakery" />
==== Kitchen ====
In 2009, Nkosi's Haven opened their new, industrial sized kitchen through generous donations from sponsors. Employed resident mothers cook to feed the large number of residents, serving hundreds of meals daily. Three well-balanced meals are provided to every resident mother, all children and volunteers.<ref name="What We Do" />
==== Leisure Block ====
[[File:Nkosi's Haven Leisure Block.jpg|thumb|A playground onsite at Nkosi's Haven Village in the Leisure Block.]] A leisure room was built at Nkosi's Haven Village to further meet the requirements to become a Child Care Centre in South Africa. Dance lessons take place in the large space on a weekly basis. The room is painted with bright colours, equipped with colourful furniture, bean bag chairs, a television, and foosball tables.<ref name="Nkosi's Haven Village" /> [[File:Nkosi's Haven Leisure Complex.jpg|thumb|One of the areas of Nkosi's Haven Leisure Complex in Johannesburg where residents play sports and host games.]]
==== Library ====
Nkosi's Haven Library provides a space for resident children to do their homework, leisurely reading, art sessions and workshops. Workshops include HIV/AIDS awareness sessions and life skills for women.<ref name="Nkosi's Haven Village" /> Through funding, the Haven continues to expand its book collection in hopes to educate and provide relevant resources for residents.
A recent project development was the implementation of [[bibliotherapy]] at the library in 2010. The bibliotherapy program used books to assist the children and young teens with coping with social, emotional and physical issues.<ref name="Tukhareli">{{cite journal|last1=Tukhareli|first1=Natalia|title=Bibliotherapy in a Library Setting: Reaching out to Vulnerable Youth|journal=The Canadian Journal of Library and Information Practice and Research|date=2011|volume=6|issue=1|pages=18}}</ref> The program identified the children's needs and used a variety of programs to help eradicate the isolation of people living with HIV/AIDS through education, self-awareness, skill development, and recreation.<ref name="Tukhareli" /> Some sessions included storytelling, reading aloud, and "The Wall of Happiness Sessions" in which participants openly discussed what made them happy with the facilitator.<ref name="Tukhareli" /> The program was made available to all residents at Nkosi's Haven, including orphans and those who were free of HIV/AIDS in order to increase overall awareness. Results of the program showed success among residents, with 92% of young participants demonstrating increased knowledge and understanding about HIV/AIDS related issues, 78% demonstrating an increase in comfort and decrease in fear around HIV/AIDS related issues, and 91% of adults demonstrating an improvement in self-esteem and optimistic attitudes.<ref name="Tukhareli" />
==== Music and Arts ====
A music and arts centre has been built onsite for resident use. This centre includes a keyboard and drums and is also a space that is used by the choir. Due to limited space and resources, Nkosi's Haven relies on the help of volunteers to teach music and arts lessons onsite. Programs are run year-round for mothers and their children.<ref name="Nkosi's Haven Village" />
An ongoing workshop is artsINSIDEOUT's annual two-week art camp that runs at Nkosi's Haven. With the help of ASTEP (Artists Striving to End Poverty), a unique art program featuring successful and competitive professionals from all areas of art including students and graduates from [[Juilliard]], ASTEP volunteer artists use storytelling, singing, acting, dancing and visual arts to inspire the youth at Nkosi's Haven to build community, consciousness and self-awareness.<ref name="Artists Striving to End Poverty">{{cite web|last1=Artists Striving to End Poverty|title=South Africa Program|url=https://www.astep.org/artsinsideout/|website=www.astep.org|publisher=Artists Striving to End Poverty|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> To date, artsINSIDEOUT has organized trips to Nkosi's Haven for 6 years and has provided funding for year-round programming, including workshops and cultural programs. Local artists are invited to join the diverse artsINSIDEOUT team to enhance cultural programs available to Nkosi's Haven.
==== Sickbay ====
In 2006, Nkosi's Haven Village completed the [[Sick bay|Sickbay]], consisting of a 9-bed unit, qualified nursing staff, and family physicians to help care for HIV positive residents. Many residents are sick due to AIDS related illnesses and are being administered quality treatment and ARV's as needed.<ref name="Nkosi's Haven Village" />
==== Therapy Block ====
All children at Nkosi's Haven Village receive various forms of therapy, including [[Therapy|remedial]], [[Play therapy|play]], [[Occupational therapy|occupational]] and [[Speech therapy|speech]].<ref name="What We Do" /> The therapy block was completed in December 2009 and employs two full-time therapists onsite to assist residents living with HIV/AIDS. Therapists also assist with helping resident mothers disclose their HIV status to their children.<ref name="Nkosi's Haven Village" />
==== Workshops and classrooms ====
Nkosi's Haven Village has one classroom and two workshops that act as a site for homework and afterschool programs. These areas offer skill-building workshops on a regular basis for residents to learn various skills such as knitting, pottery, resume writing, and more.<ref name="Nkosi's Haven Village" />
With the help of BT South Africa, an ICT infrastructure company, Nkosi's Haven opened a communications centre in 2010. The room comes equipped with computer monitors valued at R100,000 which allows the youth at Nkosi's Haven to videoconference and chat with their mentors and friends worldwide.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.itweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=39569|title=BT helps children, mothers of Nkosi's Haven in SA reach for better future|last=BT|first=|date=9 December 2010|website=www.itweb.co.za|publisher=ITWeb Limited|access-date=6 December 2016}}</ref> Infinite Family, an American organization that enables children living with HIV/AIDS to connect with mentors worldwide, has provided more than 50 youth at Nkosi's Haven with mentors.<ref name=":0" />
This room is also used to assist resident youth with their homework.
==== Nkosi's Haven 4life Farm ==== Nkosi's Haven 4Life Farm, located 50 km south of Johannesburg, has been in operation since 2008. The farm is 12 acres and currently provides crops for meals at Nkosi's Haven Village. Foundation 4Life has helped support Nkosi's Haven for years and made contributions that helped begin the production of the farm.<ref name="Farm">{{cite web|last1=Nkosi's Haven|title=Nkosi's Haven 4Life Farm|url=http://nkosishaven.org/what-we-do/nkosis-4life-farm/|website=www.nkosishaven.org|publisher=Nkosi's Haven|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Foundation 4Life|title=4Life Executives Visit Nkosi’s Haven|url=http://www.foundation4life.org/en/news/categories/20|website=www.foundation4life.org/|publisher=4Life Trademarks|accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref>
Within the next 5 years of full operation, Nkosi's Haven 4LIFE farm aims to implement a self-sustaining style of living in which mothers living with HIV/AIDS and their children from a neighbouring township and the surrounding area will assist in growing organic food to serve themselves, Nkosi's Haven's residents, and the local markets and supermarkets. The goal is to produce crops for sale in supermarket chains in South Africa once the farm is sustainable and crops are of good standard. A number of new cottages will be built on the farm to accommodate more mothers and their children in need of Nkosi's Haven's assistance.<ref name="Farm" />
== Future projects ==
=== Preschool === Nkosi's Haven has begun construction on the premises to begin early interventions of child development, skill transfer and various forms of therapy. Given that children in South Africa are held back from attending school if they are undergoing forms of therapy, an onsite preschool bypasses those restrictions and enables youth to develop their skills while receiving therapy. Nkosi's Haven pays R1000 monthly for each toddler to attend preschool outside of Nkosi's Haven, thus, an onsite preschool will save financial resources and assist Nkosi's Haven in becoming self-sufficient and sustainable. Nkosi's Haven plans to hire certified teachers in addition to training resident mothers to assist at the preschool, also building their skills and capacity.<ref name="Nkosi's Haven Village" />
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == *[http://www.nkosishaven.org/ Official website]

revision.comment: updated the treatment section with evidence from the cochrane review 2018 information about prevention options for occupational hand irritant dermatitis
revision.text:
'''Occupational skin diseases''' are ranked among the top five occupational diseases in many countries.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Kanerva's Occupational Dermatology|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=978-3-642-02035-3|location=|pages=}}</ref>
[[Contact dermatitis|Contact Dermatitis]] due to irritation is [[inflammation]] of the skin which results from a contact with an irritant.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Irritant Dematitis|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=978-3-540-31294-9|location=|pages=}}</ref> It has been observed that this type of [[dermatitis]] does not require prior sensitization of the [[immune system]]. There have been studies to support that past or present [[Atopic dermatitis|atopic]] [[Atopic dermatitis|dermatitis]] is a risk factor for this type of [[dermatitis]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Coenraads|first=P. J.|last2=Diepgen|first2=T. L.|date=1998-02-01|title=Risk for hand eczema in employees with past or present atopic dermatitis|journal=International Archives of Occupational and Environmental Health|volume=71|issue=1|pages=7–13|issn=0340-0131|pmid=9523243|doi=10.1007/s004200050243}}</ref> Common irritants include detergents, acids, alkalies, oils, organic solvents and reducing agents.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Elsner|first=P.|date=1994-07-01|title=Irritant dermatitis in the workplace|journal=Dermatologic Clinics|volume=12|issue=3|pages=461–467|issn=0733-8635|pmid=7923942}}</ref>
The acute form of this dermatitis develops on exposure of the skin to a strong irritant or caustic chemical. This exposure can occur as a result of [[accident]] at a [[workplace]] . The irritant reaction starts to increase in its intensity within minutes to hours of exposure to the irritant and reaches its peak quickly. After the reaction has reached its peak level, it starts to heal. This process is known as decrescendo phenomenon.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Dermatotoxicology|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=978-0849397738|location=|pages=}}</ref> The most frequent potent irritants leading to this type of dermatitis are acids and alkaline solutions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eichmann|first=A.|last2=Amgwerd|first2=D.|date=1992-05-05|title=[Toxic contact dermatitis]|journal=Schweizerische Rundschau Für Medizin Praxis = Revue Suisse De Médecine Praxis|volume=81|issue=19|pages=615–617|issn=1013-2058|pmid=1589676}}</ref> The symptoms include redness and swelling of the skin along with the formation of blisters.
The chronic form occurs as a result of repeated exposure of the skin to weak irritants over long periods of time.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dahl|first=M. V.|date=1988-01-01|title=Chronic, irritant contact dermatitis: mechanisms, variables, and differentiation from other forms of contact dermatitis|journal=Advances in Dermatology|volume=3|pages=261–275|issn=0882-0880|pmid=3152823}}</ref>
Clinical manifestations of the contact dermatitis are also modified by external factors such as environmental factors (mechanical pressure, temperature, and humidity) and predisposing characteristics of the individual (age, sex, ethnic origin, preexisting skin disease, atopic skin diathesis, and anatomic region exposed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/diseases/dermatitis.html|title=Dermatitis, Irritant Contact : OSH Answers|last=Safety|first=Government of Canada, Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and|website=www.ccohs.ca|access-date=2016-03-25}}</ref>
Another occupational skin disease is glove-related hand [[urticaria]], believed to be caused by repeated wearing and removal of the gloves. It has been reported as an occupational problem among the health care workers. The reaction is caused by the latex or the [[nitrile]] present in the gloves.<ref>Glove-related hand urticaria: an increasing occupational problem amongst health care workers. Hawkey S, Abdul Ghaffar S.</ref>
==Prevention==
Prevention measures include avoidance of the irritant through its removal from the workplace or through technical shielding by the use of potent irritants in closed systems or automation, irritant replacement or removal <ref>{{Cite book|title=handbook of occupational dermatology|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> and personal protection of the workers. Low quality evidence exists for the effectiveness of certain therapies and their ability to specifically prevent hand skin irritation in the workplace. The limited evidence that does exist suggests that moisturizers used alone or in combination with a barrier cream can result in a clinically beneficial effect in the long or short-term primary prevention of occupational irritant hand dermatitis.<ref>Bauer A, Rönsch H, Elsner P, Dittmar D, Bennett C, Schuttelaar MA, Lukács J, John S, Williams HC. Interventions for preventing occupational irritant hand dermatitis. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2018, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD004414. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004414.pub3</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Occupational safety and health]] [[Category:Cutaneous conditions]]
